Award.AwardTitle: 2019 NISS Writing Workshop for Junior Researchers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2019 NISS Writing Workshop for Junior Researchers will be held at the Joint Statistical Meetings (JSM) on July 28 and 30, 2019, in Denver, CO. The participants are 25 junior researchers in statistics, biostatistics, and data science, with less than 6 years since their PhD and preference to those with less than 3 years. The writing workshop provides individual hands-on guidance and mentoring on how to write journal articles and grant proposals. Junior researchers are paired with senior editors as mentors. Previous workshops have been very successful with many workshop participants going on to become associate editors or co-editors of major statistical journals. Individuals from among the 109 graduates from 2007 to 2011, the first five years of this workshop, have held at least 23 associate editorships and one co-editorship.

Writing well is a critical but often short-changed component of the education of statisticians and data scientists. The inability to write well can hinder not only publication of a researcher's results but also success with grant proposals. Over the past several years, NISS has organized technical writing workshops for junior researchers in statistics, biostatistics and data science. The 2019 NISS writing workshop consists of two parts. The Sunday tutorial is an all-day session that covers scientific writing, as well as how to organize a paper. The workshop will cover ethical issues, writing grant proposals, strategies for journal choice, effective use of graphics, and understanding and responding to reviewers' comments. At the end of this session, participants will meet with their mentor who analyzed a paper the participant submitted prior to JSM. The Tuesday session focuses on specific issues for improving a manuscript. The website for the workshop is: https://www.niss.org/events/2019-niss-writing-workshop-junior-researchers-jsm

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF 1933743 Final Report: 2019 NISS Writing Workshop for Junior Researchers

Each year from 2007 to 2016 and 2018 the National Institute of Statistical Sciences (NISS) and the American Statistical Association (ASA) conducted a technical writing workshop at JSM.  Other statistical societies joined this workshop as a co-sponsor in 2013 and following years.  NSF provided support for some of the participants’ travel and partial housing expenses.  The workshop is designed for junior researchers to improve their scientific writing, and improve the dissemination of their scholarly work, while reducing the burden on editors and associate editors.  The 2019 Writing Workshop was held on Sunday, July 28 and Tuesday, July 30, 2019, before and during the JSM held in Denver, Colorado.  

We advertised the 2019 writing workshop in the spring and received 35 applications, of which 27 qualified.  Each applicant submitted a writing sample to be reviewed. Three applicants withdrew and decided not to attend.   The remaining 24 were assigned to mentors and invited to participate.  The participants were all recent Ph.D. graduates in Statistics or Biostatistics, and 12 were females and 12 males.  Each participant was assigned to one of the 12 mentors, mostly experienced current or past editors of statistical journals, or former NSF program officers. 

The workshop began Sunday morning with lectures and tutorials by Leland Wilkinson on organization, content, structure, and style.  A lecture by Nick Jewell provided information on how to decide where to publish, followed by a panel discussion with four current or former editors of the premier statistical journals, Xuming He, Hal Stern, David Rocke, and Nicole Lazar.  Lunch provided the setting for mentors and junior researchers to meet and discuss the issues of good writing.  In the afternoon, Susan Ellenberg discussed collaborative papers, and Peter Imrey discussed ethical issues in the context of reproducibility, authorship, giving credit and citations.  A panel including Daniel Gillen (NIH BMRD), Cheryl Eavey (NSF), and Branislav Vidakovic (NSF), moderated by Keith Crank, focused on grant writing strategies and how to prepare proposals.  The day ended with meetings between the participants and their mentors, focusing on the writing sample each participant provided to the mentor in advance. 

On Tuesday, the workshop began with a presentation by Naomi Altman, on how to revise and resubmit manuscripts, covering details of grammar, sentence structure and word choice.  A panel of senior researchers whose native language is not English, Edsel Pena, Ali Shojaie, Aleksandra Slavkovic, and Tian Zheng, discussed their experiences with technical writing in English, and their successful career paths.

After the workshop, participants were encouraged to continue their contact with their mentors and with other participants to build a network of colleagues who can assist in their careers. 

Mentors:  The mentors were selected from eligible persons who planned to be available at JSM and included the following 12 former and current editors.  The mentors and participants met during the Sunday sessions, and at the end of the workshop, to review their writing samples.  They were also encouraged to continue their conversations during the JSM.  The participants provided a corrected version of their writing sample after incorporating the mentors’ suggestions.

We surveyed the participants at the end of the workshop and received Excellent or Very Good responses from over 95% of the participants.  When asked about the individual presentations, over 90% were Excellent or Very Good for most of the workshop presentations.  Based on this feedback, and a follow-up survey after six months, the workshop was considered very beneficial.  Additional comments encouraged NISS to continue to provide this workshop for new researchers, and provided some suggestions for improvement.   

Writing Workshop participant comments included the following:

  • This workshop offers many useful suggestions such as how to select a journal. I received much useful journal-specific information.
  • Yes, thanks to the advice from my mentor, it helps me pay more attention to the use of "the" in my writing. It has also helped me think harder about how to make my writing accessible by using intuitive examples.
  • I am now more careful with grammar in writing.

 Suggestions to improve the workshop included:

  • Incorporate small writing exercises might be helpful. Providing successful grant examples would be great if possible. 
  • I wish the time could be longer (e.g., two-day workshop) 
  • Organize a writing club for participants who want to continue with keeping up with their writings. 
  • I wish the time of the workshop and the communication with mentor could be longer.
